attributes.title: Analysis of grain production and related inputs in China

q1.value: Analysis of grain production and related inputs in China

q3.value: By analyzing the data of grain output and input from 1983 to 2007, the correlation was found.

q4.value: The amount of fertilizer used in agriculture has the greatest impact on food production.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Data from 1983 to 2007 were processed.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through advertisements at local pastry shops. Participants will be paid $10 for agreeing to participate (raised to $30 if our sample size is not reached within 15 days of beginning recruitment). Participants must be at least 18 years old and be able to eat the ingredients of the pastries.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 280 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 320, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

question.value: We manipulated the percentage of sugar by mass added to brownies. The four levels of this categorical variable are: 15%, 20%, 25%, or 40% cane sugar by mass.

The single outcome variable will be the perceived tastiness of the single brownie each participant will eat. We will measure this by asking participants ‘How much did you enjoy eating the brownie’ (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being ‘not at all’, 7 being ‘a great deal’) and ‘How good did the brownie taste’ (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being ‘very bad’, 7 being ‘very good’).

We will use a  2 X 3 repeated measures ANOVA (RMANOVA) with both factors within subjects to analyze our results.  This is perhaps the most important and most complicated question within the preregistration. Ask yourself: is enough detail provided to run the same analysis again with the information provided by the user? Be aware for instances where the statistical models appear specific, but actually leave openings for the precise test.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: We will verify that each subject answered each of the three tastiness indices. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the three indices of tastiness, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: Causes and Consequences of Syrian Migration into Lebanon

q1.value: Causes and Consequences of Syrian Migration into Lebanon

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This research project analyzes the largely unforeseen influx of Syrian migrants into Northern Lebanon in recent years. We draw on a population-level survey to tackle four related questions. First, we explore which variables causally affect Syrian refugees' intentons to migrate onwards toward the European Union. Second, we ask whether the act of migration itself has detrimental effects on social capital. Fourth, we explore whether exposure of native Lebanese individuals to Syrian refugees reduces individual-level social capital toward the in- and out-group. Last, we explore whether exposure to Syrian refugees leads Lebanese individuals to change their attitudes and pro-social behavior toward another salient migrant group: Palestinians. This pre-analysis plan outlines the analyses we plan to conduct, honing in on our sampling, measurement and estimation strategy.

q16.value: Cultural openness in receiving countries increases individuals' intention to migrate. Economic prosperity in receiving countries increases individuals' intention to migrate. Border openness of receiving countries increases individuals' intention to migrate. Poverty in sending countries increases individuals' intention to migrate. Insecurity in sending countries increases individuals' intention to migrate. Exposure to refugees increases pro-social behavior within the host population. Exposure to refugees decreases pro-social behavior of the host population toward refugees. Exposure to refugees decreases pro-social behavior of the host population toward existing migrants.

q17.value: Using survey data from Northern Lebanon and experimental as well as quasi-experimental variation.

Second, we ask whether the act of migration itself has detrimental effects on social capital. Fourth, we explore whether exposure of native Lebanese individuals to Syrian refugees reduces individual-level social capital toward the in- and out-group. Last, we explore whether exposure to Syrian refugees leads Lebanese individuals to change their attitudes and pro-social behavior toward another salient migrant group: Palestinians. This pre-analysis plan outlines the analyses we plan to conduct, honing in on our sampling, measurement and estimation strategy.

Exposure to refugees increases pro-social behavior within the host population. Exposure to refugees decreases pro-social behavior of the host population toward refugees. Exposure to refugees decreases pro-social behavior of the host population toward existing migrants.

summary.value:
In this project, we are interested in participants' cultural background and their decisions in a sports simulation. We will present two types of football simulation (n = 60 trials) to participants (in random order). In all trails, participants will be asked to pass the football to either a friend or a stranger. In half of the trails, the friend is in a better position whereas in the other half the stranger is in a better position. 

Please see this link for the complete study: https://research.millisecond.com/savanik/footballsimulationstudymarch2020.web

We hypothesize that those primed with a collectivist mindset will make more errors in the football simulation task, and specifically will make more errors in trails where a stranger is in a better position.

In terms of sample size, we assume a moderate effect size of d = .35 (one-tailed - as we are pre-registering a directional hypothesis). As a result, we will recruit N = 200 students to achieve a .80 power. 

Mean differences between the two experimental groups will be analyzed using ANOVA.   

All study materials, including the experimental manipulation, precise procedures, etc. are included in the attached document.

We hypothesize that those primed with a collectivist mindset will make more errors in the football simulation task, and specifically will make more errors in trails where a stranger is in a better position.

attributes.title: How does neural processing of repeated search targets differ for nameable versus unnameable objects?

q1.value: How does neural processing of repeated search targets differ for nameable versus unnameable objects?

q2.value: Lauren Williams, Trafton Drew, David Alonso, Mark Lavelle, Jacob Bedke

q3.value:
In previous research (Drew, Williams, Jones, & Luria, 2018), we found that artificial stimuli (Landolt Cs) are processed fundamentally differently than real-world stimuli in a repeated target visual search task. Specifically, an ERP component (CDA) associated with visual working memory (VWM) decreased in amplitude at the same rate with target repetition between stimulus types. However, the real-world stimuli elicited ERP components associated with long-term memory (LTM) engagement (N400) and attentional selection (N2pc) with target repetition. 

This research suggests the behavioral benefits observed for real-world stimuli may be due to the ability to recruit semantic associations in LTM in preparation for visual search, but these effects do not lead to differences in VWM engagement. However, Landolt Cs and real-world stimuli differ in a number of other aspects, including visual complexity. In this experiment, we aim to replicate previous findings using perceptually similar target objects that fall into two categories: easily accessible, nameable objects and objects lacking a common, accessible name.

Research Questions:

1) Is there a behavioral benefit for nameable objects relative to unnameable objects with target repetition?

2) How do the observed electrophysiological correlates of VWM, LTM, and attentional selection differ between nameable and unnameable objects with target repetition?

q4.value:
We predict that nameable objects will have a behavioral benefit relative to unnamable objects during search due to aid from semantic associations in LTM. In accordance with these behavioral benefits, event-related potentials related to LTM will be enhanced with target repetition relative to unnameable objects. Although previous research (Drew et al., 2018) suggests the event-related potentials related to VWM should be relatively consistent between these categories, we predict that VWM resources will decrease at a faster rate for objects with existing associations in LTM in this comparison between more visually-matched stimuli. Specifically:

- Response time will be shorter for nameable than unnameable targets (main effect) and will decrease at a faster rate with target repetition (interaction), suggesting that objects with existing associations in LTM benefit from target repetition more than objects without those associations. 

- Accuracy will be higher for nameable than unnameable targets (main effect) and will increase at a faster rate with target repetition (interaction), suggesting that objects with existing associations in LTM benefit from target repetition more than objects without those associations.  

- N2 amplitude will be smaller (i.e. less negative) for nameable than unnameable targets (main effect) and will decrease at a faster rate with target repetition (interaction), suggesting that objects with semantic information elicit a smaller novelty response than unnameable objects. 

- N400 amplitude will be smaller (i.e. less negative) for nameable than unnameable targets (main effect) and will decrease at a faster rate with target repetition (interaction), suggesting that nameable objects show a greater reliance on LTM resources with target repetition than unnameable objects. 

- NSW amplitude will be smaller (i.e. less negative) for nameable than unnameable targets (main effect) and will decrease at a faster rate with target repetition (interaction), suggesting that objects with existing LTM representations can be offloaded from VWM more easily with target repetition.  

- N2pc amplitude will be larger (i.e., more negative) for nameable than unnameable targets (main effect) and will increase at a faster rate with target repetition (interaction), suggesting enhanced attentional selection for targets with existing LTM representations.

- CDA amplitude will be smaller (i.e., less negative) for nameable than unnameable targets (main effect) and will decrease at a faster rate with target repetition (interaction), suggesting that objects with existing LTM representations can be offloaded from VWM more easily with target repetition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We are using a within-subjects design. Each participant will participate in all conditions of the study.

q9.value: Targets and distractors will be randomly selected from a nameable stimulus set (subset of Brady, Konkle, Alvarez, & Oliva, 2008) or an unnameable stimulus set (the NOUN database: http://www.sussex.ac.uk/wordlab/noun) for each participant. In addition, our lab created some ‘unnamable stimuli in order to ensure that there were enough unique items in this category. We will code for whether a given object is from the original NOUN database or newly created and test to determine whether these different object types yield different behavioral or electrophysiological results. All targets of one target category (i.e. nameable or unnameable) set will be shown prior to the other target category (i.e. unnameable or nameable), and the order of conditions will be counterbalanced between subjects.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the University of Utah and the local community through flyers and the University of Utah participant pool. Participants will receive compensation in the form of course credit or $15 an hour. Exclusionary criteria includes uncorrected vision impairments, neurological disorders, and colorblindness.

q14.value: Previous research (Drew, Williams, Jones, & Luria, 2018) has demonstrated that a sample size of at least 16 should be large enough to detect these effects.

q15.value: Data collection will stop after 20 participants. Participants with missing data (i.e., excessive EEG artifacts or failure to finish the study) will be replaced until there are 20 participants in the final dataset.

question.value:
The study has two conditions: nameable objects (condition 1) and unnameable objects (condition 2). 

Each trial will begin with a jittered (800-1000ms) fixation period. Participants will then be cued to attend to a lateralized target using a blue or green frame (counterbalanced across participants). The target will remain on the screen for 100 ms followed by a retention interval of 900ms. Participants will then search for their target object among a circular array of 8 objects. The target object will be present (50%) or absent (50%) and participants will indicate target presence/absence using the ‘F’ and ‘J’ keys on the keyboard (counterbalanced across participants). The same target will be repeated 5 consecutive times. Each trial will end with 800 ms blink interval. The word “change” will be displayed on the screen during this interval after a given target has been searched for 5 times. During half of the experiment this procedure will be completed on objects that can be named by the participants (e.g., a dog) and the other half on objects that can’t be readily named (e.g., a circular thing with bumps).

Behavioral Measures:

- Response Time

Visual search reaction times greater than 5000ms or lesser than 200ms will be excluded. Trials with incorrect responses will also be excluded from reaction time analyses.

- Accuracy

ERP Measures: 

- Mean amplitude of the N2 from 200-250ms in non-lateralized waveforms at average of electrodes Cz and Fz.

- Mean amplitude of the N400 from 350-450ms in non-lateralized waveforms at average of electrodes Cz and Fz.

- Mean amplitude of the NSW from 475-700ms in non-lateralized waveforms at electrode Cz.

- Mean amplitude of the N2pc from 200-300ms in the lateralized waveforms in average of electrodes PO7/8 and P7/8.

- Mean amplitude of the CDA from 300-1000ms in the lateralized waveforms in average of electrodes PO7/8 and P7/8.

Lateralized components (N2pc and CDA) will be calculated by averaging the data from PO7/8 and P7/8 and subtracting the contralateral electrode sites from the ipsilateral electrode sites with respect to cued target location.

We will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with 2 factors (repetition & object type) and 5 levels (rep 1, rep 2, rep 3, rep 4, & rep 5) for each dependent variable. If the results from the ANOVA are significant, Tukey’s multiple comparisons test will be used to determine which conditions differ from the rest. 

Greenhouse-Geisser corrections will be applied in any case where sphericity assumptions are violated.

q22.value: Trials with blinks, eye-movements, excessive noise, or other large artifacts in their EEG data will be excluded. Eye-movements will be detected using a step function on the HEOG channel (starting threshold 40µV). Blinks and other artifacts will be detected using a moving window (starting threshold 140µV). Thresholds for individual participants will be adjusted as necessary to increase the signal to noise ratio. Participants with more than 30% of trials rejected will be excluded from the final analysis.

q23.value: Prior to looking at the data, participants with missing behavioral or EEG data will be excluded from analysis.

q24.value:
- Mean amplitude of the N170 from 150-200ms in non-lateralized waveforms at average of electrodes Cz and Fz.

- Mean amplitude of the early CDA (300-650ms) versus late CDA (650-1000ms) in the lateralized waveforms in average of electrodes PO7/8 and P7/8.

This research suggests the behavioral benefits observed for real-world stimuli may be due to the ability to recruit semantic associations in LTM in preparation for visual search, but these effects do not lead to differences in VWM engagement. However, Landolt Cs and real-world stimuli differ in a number of other aspects, including visual complexity. Behavioral Measures:

- Response Time

Visual search reaction times greater than 5000ms or lesser than 200ms will be excluded. Trials with incorrect responses will also be excluded from reaction time analyses.

- Accuracy

ERP Measures: 

- Mean amplitude of the N2 from 200-250ms in non-lateralized waveforms at average of electrodes Cz and Fz.

registration_responses.q19.question:
We will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with 2 factors (repetition & object type) and 5 levels (rep 1, rep 2, rep 3, rep 4, & rep 5) for each dependent variable. If the results from the ANOVA are significant, Tukey’s multiple comparisons test will be used to determine which conditions differ from the rest. 

Greenhouse-Geisser corrections will be applied in any case where sphericity assumptions are violated.

q3.value: The purpose of the present study is to identify how participants associate different velocity profiles (fast and slow) of a moving object to the spatial dimensions of a target. Therefore, we will manipulate the velocity and the stability of target's spatial dimensions.

q4.value: Regarding our first between subject factor, stability, we expect participants in our fully stable condition to associate one velocity profile to one location (for example: fast > near; slow > far); in the fully unstable condition we expect a similar association, but given the numerous changes in location this mapping might take longer to emerge. In our two mixed conditions, in which we manipulate either relative distances (TTD condition) or absolute distances (OTD condition). With these two conditions we would like to see which of these two distances leads participants to create velocity-space mappings more easily.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Mixed study design with two between subject factors: stability and instability, each with two levels (stability yes; stability no; instability yes; instability no), and a within subject factor: velocity, with two levels (fast movement, slow movement)

q9.value: Block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of four equally sized, predetermined blocks. These blocks differ across conditions. Trials within each block (8 per block, so a total of 32 trials) will also be randomized. The random number used to assign participants to each condition is created using Psychopy (see code)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via Prolifics, and will be paid £1.26 for taking part in a 10 min experiment

q13.value: Each of our four between subject conditions will have a total of 48 participants (a total of 192 participants)

question.value: We will manipulate the velocity of the movements (fast and slow), as a within factor. The stability of the targets will be manipulated as a between subject factor. Stability can be full (fully stable) mixed 1 (fixed OTD), mixed 2 (fixed TTD) or none (fully unstable)
The single outcome variable is the choice: near or far target. Participants will be asked to press one of two keys
We plan to use a 2 x 2 x 2 mixed ANOVA with both between and one within subject factor. Maybe, we will also try to look at differences in choice between the different blocks of trials using T-test.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded if they didn't complete the task or if they report any technical problem at the end of the experiment

q23.value: We will not include data of incomplete data in our analyses

q24.value: We expect to find differences in the way participants map the two velocities to the different targets presented. Therefore, we will look for differences in choice within each condition, depending on the velocity of the movement presented to participants. We also expect to find differences in how stable this mapping is across conditions. Therefore, we plan to analyse differences in the choices made across blocks of trials, across conditions

In our two mixed conditions, in which we manipulate either relative distances (TTD condition) or absolute distances (OTD condition). With these two conditions we would like to see which of these two distances leads participants to create velocity-space mappings more easily.

Trials within each block (8 per block, so a total of 32 trials) will also be randomized. The random number used to assign participants to each condition is created using Psychopy (see code)
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Each of our four between subject conditions will have a total of 48 participants (a total of 192 participants)
registration_responses.q22: Participants will be excluded if they didn't complete the task or if they report any technical problem at the end of the experiment
registration_responses.q23: We will not include data of incomplete data in our analyses
registration_responses.q24: We expect to find differences in the way participants map the two velocities to the different targets presented. Therefore, we will look for differences in choice within each condition, depending on the velocity of the movement presented to participants. We also expect to find differences in how stable this mapping is across conditions. Therefore, we plan to analyse differences in the choices made across blocks of trials, across conditions
registration_responses.q8.question: Mixed study design with two between subject factors: stability and instability, each with two levels (stability yes; stability no; instability yes; instability no), and a within subject factor: velocity, with two levels (fast movement, slow movement)
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited via Prolifics, and will be paid £1.26 for taking part in a 10 min experiment
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate the velocity of the movements (fast and slow), as a within factor. The stability of the targets will be manipulated as a between subject factor. Stability can be full (fully stable) mixed 1 (fixed OTD), mixed 2 (fixed TTD) or none (fully unstable)
registration_responses.q17.question: The single outcome variable is the choice: near or far target. Participants will be asked to press one of two keys
registration_responses.q19.question: We plan to use a 2 x 2 x 2 mixed ANOVA with both between and one within subject factor. Maybe, we will also try to look at differences in choice between the different blocks of trials using T-test.

attributes.title: Resource Abundance and Allocation as an Antecedent to Stereotype Content
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value:
This experiment uses three independent variables in a between participant design.

Resource availability - vignettes will manipulate whether resources are abundant or scarce
Resource allocation - vignettes will manipulate whether resources are distributed equitably or un-equitably based on a hierarchy
Prior out group member status - vignettes will manipulate whether the out group members were perceived as being lower, middle, or upper status in their former society

All participants will receive one vignette describing a fictional society that varies based on resource availability and allocation. Additionally, the vignette will describe the arrival of a new out group to the society noting their prior perceived status in their former society.

question2b.value:
Perceived warmth
Perceived competence
Perceived status 
Perceived threat

question10b.value: All materials will be posted online and presented to participants through a Qualtrics. Participants will first be randomly assigned to condition in which they receive a vignette that varies in the description of resource availability, resource allocation, and previous status of immigrant group (2x2x3). Next, participants will be asked about their perceptions of the immigrant group. They will be asked to report their perceived status, threat, warmth, and competence of the immigrants in that order. Finally, they will be asked to report some non-identifying demographic information about themselves.

question4b.value: There are no planned restrictions for pre-selection.

question5b.value: It is planned to recruit undergraduate students from the university subject pool. Data will be collected using online surveys.

question6b.value: The planned sample size is based upon a power analysis hypothesizing a small to medium effect of conditions. Since only one resource related variable will be used in analyses at a single time, the power analysis is based on a two-way interaction between resource allocation conditions (2 - conditions) and prior out group status condition (3 - conditions). This model requires the most power to adequately assess the effects of condition, thus our sample size is suggested to be 337.

question7b.value: We will aim to recruit no more than 400 total participants to be cautious of data quality issues.

question8b.value: Data will be excluded if participants fail any of the three manipulation checks

question1a.value:
1. Resource Availability will negatively influence perceptions of out group threat
2. Resource Availability will positively influence perceptions of out group warmth
3. Out group threat perceptions will mediate the relationship between Resource Availability and out group warmth perceptions such that lower perceptions of threat will lead to higher perceptions of out group warmth
4. Resource Allocation will interact with prior status of out group members to predict current out group status perceptions
5. Current out group status perceptions will mediate the relationship between resource allocation and perceived competence of out group members

question2a.value:
An interaction between resource allocation and prior status of the out group is predicted such that when resources are distributed equitably, prior status of the out group will have a smaller influence on current perceived status of the out group. When resources are allocated based on an un-equitable hierarchy, prior status will have a stronger relationship with current status such that prior low status out group members will be perceived as being currently low status and prior high status out group members will be perceived as being currently high status group members.

This influence on current perceptions of status is meant to lead to perceptions of out group competence following a similar pattern.

question3a.value:
Manipulation checks will ask participants to correctly identify whether:
Resources on the colony were described as scarce or abundant
Resources on the colony were described as being allocated equitably or very un-equitably based on a hierarchy
Prior status of the out group members before they came to the colony were lower, middle, or upper class

question5a.value:
Overall, the purpose of this study is to expand the stereotype content model to consider the influence of societal level factors on perceptions of outgroup members. Specifically, how the availability and distribution of resources in a given society may influence stereotype content of outgroup members. 

The connection of resource availability to warmth, could be explained by realistic group conflict theory. In essence, this theory posits that outgroup members are perceived more negatively under conditions that foster competition. Therefore, this theory explains how individuals would be more likely to perceive outgroup members as warm when resources are scarce compared to when they are abundant.

To connect resource allocation with competence, we follow the rationale of system justification theory to predict how the immigrants will be perceived. When resources are allocated less equitably, it is predicted that participants will perceive high status immigrants as more deserving and competent and the low status immigrants as less competent due to their relatively lower status. However, when resources are perceived to be allocated more equitably, this would in theory tighten relative status differences thus lifting relative competence perceptions of the low status immigrants up, and bringing the relative competence perceptions of high status immigrants down compared to the non-equitable condition. System justification theory explains this pattern in order to justify the allocation of resources so that the system would be perceived as fair in both conditions.

question1c.value:
Resource Availability
Threat


All variables are measured using existing scales that are all self-report measures

attributes.title: The Effects of Group Labels' Similarity on Inferences About Intergroup Distinctiveness

q1.value: The Effects of Group Labels' Similarity on Inferences About Intergroup Distinctiveness

q3.value: In this study we are asking whether people would use the arbitrary symbols that the novel social groups are identified with to make inferences about the characteristics of these groups. Specifically, we are asking whether people would perceive two minimal social groups (e.g. Group X and Group Y) more similar to each other when the two groups have similar sounding labels compared to the cases in which they have different sounding labels.

q4.value:
We expect that people would perceive two minimal social groups (e.g. Group X and Group Y) more similar to each other when the labels of these two groups sound similar compared to the cases in which these labels sound different from each other. 

Specifically, we hypothesize that compared to the similar sounding labels condition, participants in the different sounding labels condition would infer more strongly that:
1) the similarity between in-group members would be greater than the similarity between the members of two different groups
2) A member of the Group X would allocate more resources for Group X than for Group Y

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Participants will be assigned to one of these two between subject conditions: a) small difference (Group X and Group Y have similar sounding labels [i.e. Group X will be names as the Aalborg Group and Group Y will be named as the Alaborg Group]) b) large difference (Group X and Group Y have different sounding labels [i.e. Group X will be names as the Borrering Group and Group Y will be named as the Skalunda Group])

q9.value: Each participant will be assigned to one of the between subjects conditions according to Qualtrics' automatic randomization criteria with the only consideration being allocating an equal number of sample size to each cell.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants on Mturk Prime US database will be invited to participate in the study in exchange of one US Dollar for their participation.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200 participants (N = 100 per cell).

question.value:
DV1: The difference score between these two questions:
“How similar is a Group X member to a typical Group X member?” (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being “very different”, 7 being “very similar”)
and 
“How similar is a Group X member to a typical Group Y member?” (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being “very different”, 7 being “very similar”)

DV2: The difference score between the amount of money allocated to Group X vs 
          Group Y by a member of one of these groups, measured by this question:

“Think about a member of the Group X. This person is responsible for preparing two dinner parties; one for the Group X and one for the Group Y. This person has a 300$ budget in total for both dinners. How much money, do you think, this person would allocate for the dinner of each group?”

The effects of the difference between group labels (large [i.e. different sounding labels] vs small [i.e. similar sounding labels]) will be tested using a one way between-subjects ANOVA for each dependent variable.

q22.value: Participants who fail to answer the attention check question (i.e. failing to identify the group labels that they saw in the experiment) will be excluded from the analyses.

q24.value:
We expect certain demographic traits and political affiliation of participants may be related to the way that participants attend to group identification cues. Therefore, we will look for possible relationships between demographic variables (age and gender) and political affiliation and the dependent variables.

Since the groups will be named after Scandinavian cities, these names might be familiar to some participants, and this familiarity might affect their perception of the groups. Hence, we will ask participants whether they have heard of these names before. Data will be tested with and without the participants who are familiar with these names.

attributes.title: Exercise therapy in the prevention of non-contact musculoskeletal soccer injuries: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials

q1.value: Exercise therapy in the prevention of non-contact musculoskeletal soccer injuries: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials

q2.value: Vitor N Lage, Barbara AB Roch, Rafael Z Pinto, Thales R Souza, Italo Ribeiro Lemes

q3.value: There is no study investigating whether exercise would prevent musculoskeletal soccer injuries. Therefore, our research question is: Is exercise therapy effective in reducing the incidence of musculoskeletal soccer injuries?

q4.value: Exercise therapy will help to prevent musculoskeletal soccer injuries.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review and meta-analysis

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The search will be performed in eight electronic databases: EMBASE, MEDLINE, the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), CINAHL, SPORTDiscus and PEDro.We will also search for potential ongoing or unpublished trials by searching the following registers:
ClinicalTrials.gov, the International Standard Randomized Controlled Trial Number Register (IRSCTN), the Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ANZCTR). This search will be aided by the World Health Organization (WHO) – International Clinical Trials Registry Platform search portal.The search strategy will be conducted using a combination of search terms related to soccer, prevention and randomized controlled clinical trials.Citation tracking will be performed in relevant publications of the field.The search will not be restricted to any language or date of publication.
Two independent reviewers will conduct the title and abstract screening. Moreover, two independent reviewers will assess the full-text of potentially eligible articles following the inclusion criteria. In the case of disagreement, a third reviewer will be consulted to arbitrate. A reason for exclusion will be provided for each full-text. Data extraction from included studies will be performed using a standardized data extraction form. The following data will be extracted: study design; participant characteristics (sample source, inclusion and exclusion criteria, age, and sex); sample size; details of study treatment and control; type of intervention; time points assessment; and outcomes relevant to the review (type of measure and results).
Non-contact musculoskeletal injury will be considered as the primary outcome of this review.
Musculoskeletal injury rate per 1000 hours of exposure.

We will calculate the injury incidence rate by dividing the number of incident injuries divided by the total time-at-risk multiplied by 1000 as this accommodates variations in exposure time of individual soccer players. Pooled estimates will be calculated using the random-effects model. If possible we will calculate the number needed to treat (NNT) by comparing the proportion of injured players in the intervention and control groups.

q24.value: If possible a subgroup analysis will be conducted to explore whether the design of the preventive exercise therapy (multimodal vs unimodal)l, may influence the treatment effect.

q25.value:
Intervention:
Studies investigating exercise therapy programs designed to prevent musculoskeletal soccer injuries will be considered eligible. For the purpose of this review, we will consider as a preventive exercise therapy any systematic and planned program focusing on improving the performance of body movements or exercises which aims to prevent injuries.
Exercise therapy is defined as any exercise that is performed or practiced to develop or improve a specific function or skill to develop and maintain physical fitness.

Comparator:
Trials or multiple-arm trials including comparators such as no intervention, usual training routine or minimal intervention (e.g. education, advice, waiting list and self-care) will be considered eligible.

Types of study to be included:
We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs).

Risk of bias assessment:
The Physiotherapy Evidence Database (PEDro) scale will be used to assess risk of bias among included studies. The PEDro scale has been found to be reliable [1] and valid [2] tool in evaluating risk of bias. If consensus cannot be reached, a third reviewer will arbitrate. If the scores are available in the PEDro database, these scores will be used.Quality of overall evidence will be evaluated using Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) system [3]. The four domains (e.g.study design and risk of bias, inconsistency, imprecision and publication bias) will be used to downgrade the quality of evidence from high to low. Indirectness will not be considered because we will include a
specific intervention in a specific population.

[1] Maher CG, Sherrington C, Herbert R, et al. Reliability of the PEDro scale for rating quality of randomized controlled trials. Phys Ther. 2003, 83:713-21.
[2] Macedo LG,Elkins MR, Maher CG, et al. There was evidence of convergent and construct validity of Physiotherapy Evidence Database quality scale for physiotherapy trials. J Clin Epidemiol. 2010, 63:920-5.
[3] Atkins D, BestD, Briss PA, et al. Grading quality of evidence and strength of recommendations. BMJ 2004;328(7454):1490
